thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: Windsor owners cash out of historic city office for $39m
thread.title_full: Windsor owners cash out of historic city office for $39m

title: Windsor owners cash out of historic city office for $39m
text:
AMP Capital has acquired the 425 Collins Street building for $39 million from the Indonesian-based Halim family.
An Indonesian group behind a controversial bid to redevelop Melbourne's Windsor Hotel is cashing out, offloading another historic sandstone city building in Collins Street for $39 million.
AMP Capital beat off investors and international hotel operators to buy a heritage-listed building at 425 Collins Street from the Halim Group, a company controlled by the Indonesia-based Halim family who also own the 19th-century Windsor Hotel on Spring Street.
The deal suggests the Halim Group is cashing out ahead of a last-ditch bid to prevent the Windsor Hotel's closure after a state government decision not to grant the company an extension to its permit to build a 26-storey tower at the hotel's rear.
Earlier this month, Halim Group confirmed it was seeking a review of the government's decision at the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal.
Advertisement It is appealing on the grounds that builders it approached to carry out the work on the $330 million redevelopment say it would be "impossible" to finish the works by January 2017, when the planning permit runs out.
The Windsor redevelopment first gained planning approval in 2010 but soon became mired in controversy and delays which prompted planning minister Richard Wynne in July to urge the Halims to "do the right thing ... and get on with construction."
VCAT has yet to decide the appeal.
Spokesman Michael Smith said Halim Group "hadn't given up the Windsor".
The sale of 425 Collins was unrelated. "They just thought it was a good time to sell. They bought at the right time and they're selling at the right time," he said.
The purchase is not AMP's first association with the classic 10-level building â€“ it originally developed the imposing structure on the corner of Collins and Market streets in 1931 as its Melbourne office.
The building's tenant list includes the Halim Group's head office, Australian Stock Report, Carepark and retailers Men+Co, Ms Collins and Terra Firma on ground level.
CBRE's Kiran Pillai, Mark Wizel and Josh Rutman handled the sale.
Mr Rutman said the high ceilings and historic features attracted strong interest from hoteliers looking to convert the Bates, Smart and McCutcheon designed space into prime Collins Street accommodation.
"It's almost too good as an office, though. A developer would have to wait at least five years to get the tenants out," Mr Rutman said.
AMP's Wholesale Australian Property Fund paid a passing yield of 5.07 per cent for the classic property.
The fund has been an active player recently settling on the Stud Park Shopping centre in Rowville for $154 million.
